title: Over-Engineering Early MVP
description: Built a complex microservices architecture for what should have been a simple MVP
context: Early startup project with limited resources and unproven market fit
mistakes: Spent 3 months on infrastructure instead of product
Ignored YAGNI (You Ain't Gonna Need It) principle
lesson: Start simple, scale when needed. MVP should prove concept, not architecture.
impact: 6 months delay in market validation, wasted $15k in cloud costs
now: Now I start with monolith, split when scale demands it

title: Ignoring Technical Debt
description: Pushed for rapid feature development without addressing growing technical debt
context: Fast-growing SaaS with pressure to deliver new features
lesson: Technical debt compounds. Small investments in quality save huge costs later.
impact: Feature development slowed by 70% after 1 year, required 3-month rewrite
now: Now I enforce code reviews, testing, and allocate 20% time for refactoring

title: Poor Requirements Gathering
description: Built the wrong product by not understanding client needs deeply enough
context: Enterprise client with complex business processes
lesson: Spend twice as much time understanding the problem as building the solution.
impact: 80% of features unused, required complete redesign
now: Now I do deep discovery, create prototypes, and validate with real users

title: Underestimating Maintenance
description: Didn't account for ongoing maintenance costs in project pricing
mistakes: Didn't plan for updates and security patches
lesson: Software is a living product, not a one-time deliverable. Price accordingly.
impact: Lost money on maintenance, strained client relationship
now: Now I offer clear maintenance plans and scope-based pricing
